sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What i'st?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, keep me pray from running Mad!

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: If— but, who's this I see?

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: — Good,— here's relief

sp.speaker: Lyset,
sp.l: Ah! he put's up his Purse agen, the Thief!

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What e're I say,— let it create no doubt,
Wee'l laugh anon.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Now, I must stand it out.
Hopes of his present does invite my stay.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: BLest with your Presence, once more Lucia.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: A common joy,— But with regret, Sir, I
Thus interrupt your wished Secresie.
Surely you treated with great Confidence.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What, you suspect I held Intelligence.
And think design, what accidental proves?
Cliton knows.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, he's honest, where he Loves.
Though this fresh▪ Object, to my shame, I see—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: He Courted her, indeed, but 'twas for me,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If you believe that Fool—

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What I behold,
I dare believe,— but not all I am told.

sp.speaker: Crontus.
sp.l: Then on your part, my Ruine is assur'd?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What Persecution, I for you indur'd.
Whilst a harsh Brother for Florame, this day—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I more deserve then he,— so to obey.
Much your own loss, and prejudice would be,
And you oblige your self, whilst just to me.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Take heed! least this presumption to reprove,
I yield him up— at last— my faith and love!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis but three sighs more, added to the heap.
But,— e're you do't consult, look e're you leap.
And get your heart's consent to it before

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What! would my loss affect you then no more?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What? you'l betray your self, and therefore I
Must yield my self a prey to grief— and dye!
Let it sting those it does most nearly touch.
Grief almost kill'd me last night 'twas so much;
For having known how well Florame was us'd
By you, I hasted to you much confus'd:
There wept and wail'd, and all sad means did try,
Low at your feet, to break this heart and dye.
But since I finde it inconvenient prove,
I'le blow it off, and try new fashion love.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Your fashion,— to deceive, and be ingrate.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That love's most pleasing, is least delicate,
And where we once resolve, no Jealousie,
Should

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Without reason then it ceazes me?
Nor may I credit give to my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You should pass by such things, if you were wise.
Let's make the agreement thus, 'twixt you and me:
To have no jealous thoughts,— but ever free
From all vain fears, think either's faith most true,
And if you ne're doubt me, I'le ne're doubt you.
Thus when I swear, believ't I love you well:
I'le do the same, when you Love-stories tell▪
All this observ'd, our Contract shall remain;
But the least tripp, infringes it again.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: True love, sublim'd, will all this disavow,
He makes a Monster on't, does this allow.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Allowing what we like, but makes us find
The troubles less,— pleasures more un-confin'd.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: No, he that can divided Love indure,
And not dye rather, has small courage sure?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If, in effect, this Maxime bare the sway,
Men were in danger to dye every day.
Can any lightness with your own compare,
Last night one,— now another,— so y'all are.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: The better to delude us, thus ye plead:
But, think how many th'rough such grief are dead.
And oft have had the applause of learned men.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The' example's dang'rous, I renounce it then.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Your heart's too cold, where such brave dangers are.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Let, who's will do't, and take my honours share.
Should I expire your Martyr,— for a day
Or two, perhaps, the world should hear you say
He was a Faithful Lover,— I regret
For me he dy'd!— Much I by this should get.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Is an an illustrious Memory no gain?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Heav'ns grant my Epitaph less sad, and vain!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: And yet you'l say; you love men'eretheless.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Ask but my heart, my heart which you possess.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: ORONTUS, ERASTES, LUCIA, LYSET. CLITON, LYSTOR.

sp.speaker: Erastes,
sp.l: THey do adore each other,— I am told.

sp.speaker: Lucia,—
sp.l: My Brother's here,— O Gods!

sp.speaker: Erastes▪
sp.l: I see him,— hold!

sp.speaker: Lystor.
sp.l: A Lady with him.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Then it must be she▪
'Tis Dorothea.

sp.speaker: Lucia
sp.l: Think of leaving me.

sp.speaker: Erastes—
sp.l: This night with her, he through the Garden went;
I know her—

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What? and must I then consent?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Yes, for I dare not go, till after you;
Pray lose no time, be gone,— bid me adieu.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I do obey you.— Cliton!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, what now?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Stop Lyset here, but stop her mouth close too,
Promise her any thing,— do't e're you stir.

div.stage: Orontus goes off one way, and immediately Lucia goes another.

sp.speaker: Lystor,
sp.l: She goes

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Ingrateful! but I'le follow her.
For without doubt, her woman does abide,
That if we ask who 'tis, she be deny'd.
But, following after, I her plots destroy.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: HOw shall I act the part of th' angry Boy?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: No quarter.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Such severe ill will?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Provide elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Do'st keep thy anger still
Cliton?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes still I keep't, and keep it shall.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Look up?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: — No.—

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I'le bate thee nought at all.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: What you'l forsake me,— You, whose grizled Pate,
And snuffling Nose, proclaims ye out of date?
You will forsake me,— Me, who more or less,
The whole Town dotes on, for my prettiness.
Me, whose dear Love so hotly they pursue,
It makes them look on Thee, with envy too.
Who thus abase my thoughts.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes,— you,— you,— you?
Who squeez'd my Purse, and then laugh'd at me too.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Your gifts, I'le warrant, Trick me up thus brave.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Pox, Now I apprehend this Female knave. (aside.
Before my face, your liberty's so bold
'T has made my wonted charity catch cold.
— Ev'ry one Courts you now.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: — Yes, and those words
Alone a daily Revenue affords▪

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And this to me, you think must comfort bring?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Cliton, speak wisely, and leave quarrelling.
You knew my humour, and my Method knew,
That I lov'd cloathes in fashion,— often new.
Each day I purchase somewhat, and protest
What I do cut or sow,— is of the best
Either the Draper or the Mercer sells.
And whilst my Cash holds, I do little else.
Now,— think what this must cost? For, to go neat;
Wishing, nor Witch-craft, will not do the feat:
Your Wages, whatsoever,— hardly brings
Enough for Gloves, and such small trifling things.
So that to prove too Coy, would prove my shame,
My Pride would fall,— And then Adieu— Fine Dame.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis right,— but come— to wave all you have said,
What have I reap'd for all my Wages paid?
From day to day, my Passion has encreast;
Yet with my finger ne're durst feel your— Breast.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I lov'd thee,— that's sufficient I conceive.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Lov'd me!

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: To doubt, your self were to deceive;
You know.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: I'm left in Hell, Loves Barly-break▪

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Does not six sighes a Day, my true love speak?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Great comfort that, to troubled Souls does prove.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Do you so light esteem those mark's of Love?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Just next to nothing, so I find,— And sure,
Since Love was ever held an Epicure
And glutton, when the Boy you thus do Treat,
Sighes cannot nourish th'are such hollow Meat.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I lose my time here, you but love to prate;
And thy weak reason turns my love to hate.
Adieu.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But stay, if not for Love, for Gold;
For twenty Crowns, can you One Secret hold?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: One, yes a score.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Hold! that's too much for Thee!

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I'le do't, I'le warrant, let it rest on me.
Can you disburse-em?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes,— but prethee hear!
Keep but your Tongue, out of your Mistriss' Ear.
My Master.—

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I'le conceal his Prancks,— ne're doubt.
Let's see the Money?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet told out.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Your promises on hopes, will ill succeed.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I'le pawn my Honour.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: A fair pledge indeed.
Go, I'le discover all that ever past.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Beware he do not Nooze you, too, at last.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: AT least defer it, till my troubled mind
Compos'd,— to this sad Hymen be inclin'd.
Do not precipitate—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: You hope in vain▪
By pray'r to blast, my just design again:
Yours I perceive, I read it in your soul:
But Florames Father now has my Parol,
Which I must keep,— he claims you thereupon,
And so to morrow Hymen makes you One▪

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But he so little values me, you see
He hardly.—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: That, but an effect may be
Of what's reported, by Orontus, who
Is said to have pretences for you to.
Florame alarm'd therewith, does colder prove,
Fearing his Rival, more then him you love.
From his disturbed thoughts I gather it,
Which since a mis-report does thus beget,
I ought to hasten on this Nuptial Tye,
To set all right, and them to satisfy.
Think on't, Adieu.— I'le to his Fathers run,
And there consult what more is to be done. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: In vain this Man, for Husband you'd prefer;
My Eyes herein, shall be my Counseller.
But, Lyset comes, Love take thou my defence.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I Staid thy coming with impatience.
Well,— is he found, what's his reply, tell true?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I have at once both found and lost him too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: How, did he slight the Message thou didst tell?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: You do not know him yet; sure, very well.
He's too much vers'd in's way to blanch at that.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then prethee let me know how 'tis, and what?
Didst say I wait him?— Shall I see him here?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: No doubt he'l come,— but pray beware a snare.
If you'l believe me, give him word for word;
Pay him in's own coine, but no more afford.
Engage no farther, then you find him go.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What does induce thee to speak of him so?
Is he inconstant, false?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: That shall appear,
Be Judge your self, pray, Madam do but hear.
I'th' street I met him in a certain place,
Who smiling, when he first beheld my Face,
Approach'd me with such joy, as made me deem
His Love was noble, and deserv'd esteem.
This did his words confirm, for he did say,
He ever would to you obedience pay.
Scarce were these words pronounc'd, when I protest
A Lady coming,— Here's the main oth' jest,—
— He without why, or wherefore, durst presume
To sing her the same Song, to the same Tune:
And without blushing, tho I stood close by,
Discours'd of Love to her most pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Unworthy Man,— had he the confidence
Before your Face to own a new pretence,
And mention Love to her?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Yes, in my sight.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Dissembling Traytor!

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: 'Tis his whole delight.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But, then the Lady, what became of her?
Go on.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: A long while they did there confer,
When, suddenly, ('twas plotted I dare say)
They part, and each retir'd a several way.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: And you ne're follow'd to enquire her name?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I would, and much I long'd to know the same;
But, then Orontus servant made me stand,
Who having pop't some Sweet-meats in my hand,
In earnest of some better thing e're long,
Promis'd me Mountains for to hold my tongue:
But I,— what do you think I am so base?
Then throwing all the Sweet-meats in his face,
Sirra (cry'd I) — I'le ne're prove false for these,

l.hi: Nor do I use to sell my Mistrisses▪
If I need Money, she such plenty hath
In store for me, I need not break my Faith.

sp.l: Then did my courage prompt me to engage.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Thy Zeal does ravish me.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I swell'd with rage.
What, I betray you?— Sell you? Wher's his wit?
He proffer.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Go,— thou shalt not lose by it.
In the mean time, see my unhappy Fate?
And with what reason I did all men hate:
Since this Orontus, for whose Love,— my Pride
And noble Haughtiness I laid aside;
Like a Dissembler does me slight and brave,
And puts on others Chains, who was my slave.
But,— truly this was timely brought to light,
Ere I consulted that false Man to night;
Or how to break this other Hymen ask't
Advice.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: You hope in vain, ther's promise past:
Your Father urges it, and having pow'r.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Let him urge still, I'le quash all in one hour.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: But Florame has his word, his heart, his love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Florame, at need, my help herein would prove,
Since to endeavour this our union he
Too much aversion ever met in me.
In vain these impotent old Parents try
Upon our wills to act their tyranny.
Each others coldness being mutual,
We dread not their authority at all.
But,— who is't locks that door? what is't they do?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: PRotect me, from a brother does pursue
To finde me out,— whose wrath and jealousie
For walking forth, will harshly light on me.
In vain, by twenty turns, from street to street
I sought to steal away, and he not see't.
He follow'd still, and keeping me in sight
Constrain'd me now, lest on me he should light
To step in here, where I your aid implore.
For shelter, till— this danger may blow o're.
See who 'tis begs. (she takes off her Hood.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Ah! Lucia is it thee?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: 'Tis I, whose cruel Brothers jealousie—
But, there he knocks,— to save me from his frown
Pray, feign you just now come in from the Town.
My Hood, I'le leave you.
sp.stage: she puts her hood upon Dorotheas head.

sp.speaker: Dorothea
sp.l: Hide you quickly, do.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: In here!

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Dy'e know?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Open the door, go, go.
Make haste.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: No matter, she shall make it good.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: What will he think on't?

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.stage: giving her Hood to Lyset as if she newly came into the house.
sp.l: LYset, take my Hood.
sp.stage: Lyset goes out with the Hood, and enters agen about the latter end of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Pardon th' intrusion; you may well suspect,
Void both of Love to you, and of respect.
I follow my dispair, and with much pain
The storms of my just anger now refrain.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your humour's much disturb'd to day, I find:
I thought so smooth a Calm raign'd in your mind,
That still immoveable at all events,
Your soul no anger knew, nor discontents.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: None, but for you, caus'd by my too great Faith
And Love—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then I'm the object of this wrath.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Deny, ungratefully you scorn my flame;
Deny, my Rivals happiness, your shame;
What yet I saw, must treason be confest?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Believe me, Sir, you rave!

sp.speaker: Erastis.
sp.l: But yet, at least
You will agree, since many eyes did see't,
You held discourse with him in th' open street.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Whom I follow'd after your adieu's,
Believe—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your eyes.—

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: These eyes ne're bring false newes▪
But clearly to evince, and tell your shame,
It will suffice, when I Orontus name.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Orontus!

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Yes,— that Gallant was there, to,
Whom you gave audience while he courted you.
Can you deny it still?

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: In troth 'tis fine,
I serve my Rival,— was ere Fate like mine?

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Your silence is confession.— All desires
I henceforth banish, quenching all my Fires.
A most Unfaithful She, I did adore;
But Heav'ns discovery bids my heart give o're.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This is too rash,— yet still my goodness see?
(For sure you neither know, nor speak to me.)
I pardon your blind rage, tho gone so far
As to mistake both me, and who you are▪
Think on me, whilst your tongue you fiercely whet,
And think how much you do your self forget.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: I've thought too long, and Justly have accus'd—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What you proceed?— This makes me more confus'd,
Your words so discompos'd at randome fly.
— But, pray, let's know, what makes you speak thus high?
Orontus, say you, hath my heart obtain'd.
Is it a Crime that Man my love hath gain'd?
What had I promis'd you, should hinder me?
I brake no Oaths, nor Vows, my soul was free,
If from one Letter, you this inf'rence make,
Your easiness that favour did mistake.
I love to jeast, if that will do the deed,
I'de write a hundred more such for a need.
That Paper shew'd in Mirth I much delight,
And you will find so, if you spell it right.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: What, mock me thus?— Is this the fruit at last
Of all my hopes, and all my service past?
After two years, spent in devoirs and love?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Such devoirs sometimes do but trouble prove.

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Now your proud minde does cast off all disguise.
This shews my error, and unseals my eyes;
Go, take your swinge in your unconstant will.
Leave me,— and live for your Orontus still.
Those fetters once so soft and dear, I break,
And to keep nothing that of you does speak.
That Letter, whose allurements made me burn,
Tho once my treasure I will back return.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You will oblige me, do, kinde Sir, 'tis fit▪

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: Yes, I'le restore it, make no doubt of it.
I'le haste home for it, Madam, stay that while. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: IN fine; heaven now begins on you to smile,
The Rival Lady,— she to whom I said
The false Orontus new addresses made
Is in your power, what more could fortune do?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I know, yet have maintain'd her quarrel too.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I suffer'd hitherto, but now she must,

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Speak softly, else she hears, and may distrust.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: I'le warrant her from being now so near,
She fled into the Garden out of fear.
And to return you thanks there waits thus long.
I came now thence.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: T' avenge my love and wrong,
And blast his base design, this remedy
I quickly;— stay— what's that appears to me?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: L yset.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: 'Tis Cliton.— Is your Master there? (to Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: May he come in?

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Let him not fear,
The good man's forth, tell him. (Cliton goes out.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: See now Lyset.
How both of them do fall into my net.
If from disdain of me their love take root,
One stroke may lop them both, and I will do't.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Let not fierce jealousie bear so great a sway,
But seek—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Go back, and finde out Lucia.
And when you guess Orontus may be here
Lead her this way, till she approach so near,
That having stopt her, on some other score
She may hear all we say, from yonder door,
His tongue must prate of Love when he comes in,
And I'le return as good as he can bring.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: The bait's so tempting— he will bite anon.
I think I hear him. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Quickly then, be gone▪
He's here.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: HOw Sir?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I tell thee, I, in fine
Have quitted her, and Lyset's henceforth thine.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: In earnest?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And in earnest shall be still.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Thank's Sir— Now push your fortunes where you will.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: How dear soever I this favour prize,
Yet, from your goodness this regret does rise.
That here expected by you, it may chance
Breed doubt which brings me, love— or complaisance
For your commands may seem to make it prove
More my obedience then an act of love.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.stage: appearing at the door with Lucia, whom she obliges to retire a step or two.
sp.l: Madam, a Gentleman is there you see.
Stay.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: 'Tis Orontus, Ah! false man, 'tis he!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: While you surprize me by your Complement
With art enough, you my complaints prevent.
But, say your self, what shall I now believe?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My Joy's so great, you may the truth perceive.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I doubt 'tis art.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Small reason in this case.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: A treacherous soul oft hath a smiling face.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: To be secure, this a safe way will prove,
Ask your own heart, that knows how I do love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: It owns no secrets.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: More then you confess,
Vouchsafe to hear it, it will speak no less.
Besides which, my Devoirs my love sets forth.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Which being forc'd, are but of little worth.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The Homage paid those Eyes, which rule my heart,
Are they esteem'd a force then, on your part?
That love which no self-interests defile,
That has no dross, no mixture, nought that's vile.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You set it highly forth.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: Have I not cause,
Since 'tis your Vertue only gives it lawes?
Your worth, the only motive comprehends,
Of my true love,— And such love's without ends.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I may presume it then, to be long liv'd;
This rare, this noble birth from me deriv'd;
For though, the pow'r of time most pow'rful be,
Can that e're make me cease from being me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: It were great wrong both to my Faith and Will,
To doubt my Love were not immortal still.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You speak so lavishly, I justly fear,
Least some surprizal you intended here.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Does my Sincerity suspicion give?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: They hazard much, that lightly do believe▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Hopes founded on great Merits, may be said
By being limited to be betraid.
Such ought from so firm rules not to depart,
Which lays a claim to every noble heart.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: From thence it comes, soon as your Eyes give fire
You conquer ev'ry object you desire.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: From hence it is with little fear I do
See others under-hand, attempting you.
I serve you out of love,— Erastes out
Of gain,— your Eye-sight's good, what need I doubt?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your merits do presage you cannot fail,
Set against him, you must o'reweigh the scale.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Go as it will, my self I'le satisfy.
Those shall deserve my care, that will comply:
Or if another choice they shall pursue,
th'rough their own folly.— My Faith bids adieu.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Such weakness in my choice shall never be;
This fly reproach is it address'd to me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Your lov's too scrupulous, I'le tell yee true.
Such general terms, do not reflect on you.
— But, I hear noise!

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You seem to fear,
And look—

sp.speaker: Dorothea▪
sp.l: I look't about for Lyset here.
I thought I saw her.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: So you might. I say—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What is become of her?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: She's gone this way;
I'le go and call her.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Gods! what would you do?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Shew a small proof, of my great Zeal for you.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Still with your Love suspicion does appear.
But, know, if any person were hid there
Without my leave, perhaps my woman may—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That you are guilty, Madam, who dares say?
This time you speak against your self, I see.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I've cause to fear your prying jealousie
Since yesterday you stuck the same reproach.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray do but cause your woman to approach.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: And under that pretence your doubts begin
To—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Then permit—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Erastes is within.
Put on Sir, make the naked truth appear;
Perhaps 'tis Lysets t'other Husband's there!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Well, do your pleasure, Sir, but after this.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Y'are much allarm'd.— Lyset!

sp.speaker: Lucia,
sp.stage: discovering her self suddenly to Orontus.
sp.l: AH! here she is!
Take courage man, Fate cannot be withstood.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: Cheapners enough,— this Market must be good.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What unexpected Lab'rinth am I in!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Your Wit's a Clue, will guide you out agin.

sp.speaker: Lucia,
sp.l: Well, Faithless Lover?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.,
sp.l: Lover so untrue!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What turn by turn your heart thus shar'd 'twixt two?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Inconstant!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Perjur'd!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Scornful!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Flat'ring!— Nay—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Ungrateful!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Traytor!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Have yee more to say?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: After so many Vows, without pretence—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Master, for fear o'th' worst, let's ee'n pack hence:
Should these fly on's, as some she Dragons do;
Adieu, Gallants, to Man and Mounsir too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: In fine, the truth, in spite of all your skill—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray, let me hear th' Inditement, if you will?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Can you demand, yet, what your Crime should be?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, having not the gift of Prophesie.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Deny these Treasons, are so Evident,
Shews you not falser now, then impudent.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Do not pass sentence, e're you name the Crime.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You never told me, that your heart was mine?
That you those Oaths and Vows would ne're forget?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le swear all this agen, I love ye yet,

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Can you love her, false Man, so oft did say,
Nay swear, your heart did yeild to Lucia?
And that—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: All this I'le still make good, and more.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Love me?
Yes, you

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: And me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I still adore.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Mark but his confidence, though both are by?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: In vain my love for you, I should deny,
Too well you know me not to claim a part.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Why Court you me then, if she have your heart?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: For love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: — What love?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: — True love

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: True love,— how so?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why, true love, Madam, does from Reason flow.
And Reason tells me wheresoe're I see
Beauty (like pow'r) it must adored be.
Thus whilst in each of you such Charms I meet,
I equally am drawn to baits so sweet.
Nor can you blame me for't, since whilst I do
Her beauty prize, I pay your's worship too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But, since you first, or last, must chuse, let's see
Who you'l prefer?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That still must secret be.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Come, come, you must declare.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No,— for in brief
I fear the she I leave would dye for grief.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Sir, you may chuse elsewhere, as you like best▪
Truly, you well deserve all this contest.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Nay, if you'r thus indiffrent. Here I'le vow
My constant Love. I'm Dorotheas now.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: The mighty prize I yeild with willing mind.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Had I declar'd for you, youl'd speak more kind.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Her Fortunes great, it cannot be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Disgrace is still attended with false Pride.
And yet the loss perhaps breeds trouble too.
You to whom henceforth, all my love is due,
Believe—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This sudden change admits of doubt.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Your Wit, on second thoughts will make it out.
Since your more great deserts doe you prefer.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your various humour makes me fear you erre.
You swear to every one.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: The Mode,— you see:
But as I am,— try how you like of me?

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IX.
div.stage: ARGANTE, ORONTUS, FLORAME, ERASTES, DOROTHEA, LUCIA, LYSET, CLITON.

sp.speaker: Erastes,
sp.stage: coming in before Argante, speaking to Dorothea.
sp.l: HEre is your Letter, which I would alledge,
— But— how— my Sister here?

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: Her faith I'le pledge,
I'm Father.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: O! but rather then constrain—
Your coldness gives me just cause to complain.
If false repotts alone disturb your mind;
Or cause Orontus, you in presence find:
Know, that which brings him's Lucia's love, for I—

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Sir, what you speak of me, I must deny.
My love's beyond Orontus hopes so far—

sp.speaker: Elorame,
sp.l: Then suffer me, at this time to declare,
That having dar'd at Lucia's Bed to aim,
The honour of your Sonship would be vain.
Nor can I, Sir, accept of it at last.
But here's Erastes—

sp.speaker: Erastes.
sp.l: No the Dyce is cast;
To love that false One, I shall ne're accord.
But, Sir, to you, that I may keep my word,
Lead home my Sister— You th' effect shall see.

sp.speaker: Florame,
sp.l: Adieu,— Don't envy my prosperitie.

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: WHat means all this; Does Lucia Florame love?
And is not she the object you approve;
With whom this night caught in your Love design,
You leap'd their Garden wall, and came to mine?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Sir,— 'tis high time, I should you disabuse;
Know therefore, only Love shap'd that Excuse.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: What meet my Girle by night▪ and both to dare—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray make no trouble.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: You shall Marry her.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I must consent to Wed at last, for I
Have no way else to End this Comedy?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Bring you to Marriage! Who could this fore-show?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This ends my Part, and it must needs be so.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yet the Conclusion will imperfect be;
To wind up all, Lyset should Marry me.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Do'st love her?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I dye for her.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then she's thine.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: My pretty One—

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Not yet,— the choice is mine;
Canst thou maintain me, like a Dam'sel fair?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, sure.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Hast thou wherewith?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: — Take you no care▪

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: Who will secure me?

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: He,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le do't,— give o're.

sp.speaker: Lyset.
sp.l: First lets the Money Count,— Then I'le say more.
